metadata.titel_preek: Elijah Standing before the Lord—1 Kings 17:17-24

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God acts through His servant Elijah to reverse the sentence of death and reveal His ultimate purpose of life through judgment.

tekstueel_bewijs: God has raised up men and women to stand before him
It is this God who gives power to his servants
God has brought Elijah to her hut

object.identificatie: Life/Restoration (The boy's life and the widow's knowledge of Truth)
tekstueel_bewijs: God’s ultimate purpose, which is through judgment to give deliverance, through death to give life
the child’s life returned to him
The word of the Lord from your mouth is truth
The living God of Israel himself... the thrust of the drama is guided by God

ontvanger.identificatie: The Widow of Zarephath (and by extension, the Hearer)
tekstueel_bewijs: Now I know that the word of the Lord from your mouth is truth
The promise that we may grasp and believe
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies with the Receiver (the widow) who is under the sentence of death.

tekstueel_bewijs: Elijah was a man just like us... he had no strength of his own
clothed in the supernatural power of the Holy Spirit
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject; Elijah is the instrumental Helper.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin and Death (as hostile cosmic Powers)
tekstueel_bewijs: Death is a malevolent intruder into human life, the cohort of sin
Sin (understood as a hostile Power) 'worked death'
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Death is treated not as a natural end but as a 'malevolent intruder' and 'hostile Power' that only God can overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of 'standing before the Lord' and bearing witness.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (Elijah, Luwum, the Hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ability to stand (Secondary) is entirely dependent on God's prior action and endowment (Primary).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has raised up men and women
God’s judgment will for us be life
He [Jesus] stepped into the place of judgment alone
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We are attracted to such people

voorbeelden: the gap between who we are and what we ought to be
Elijah demanded that God should behave like God’s self
Now I know that the word of the Lord... is truth
He had no strength of his own
God who gives power to his servants

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'incompetence' (lack of power) and God's 'competence' (sovereign power) to give life and enable service.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From ~S1 (Sin) to S2 (Death/Judgment) and finally to S1 (Life) through the mediation of Christ (~S2).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: God does not bypass judgment (S2) but works through it to bring life (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; death is described as a 'sentence' and 'malevolent intruder'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God is the primary actor; humans are recipients of a power they do not possess. Even the 'hero' Elijah is stripped of inherent power to highlight God's agency.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: God has raised up men and women to stand before him. You have known people like this.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Elijah had no strength of his own... It is this God who gives power.
We are not told that this widow had faith... We are told only that Jesus looked upon her and had compassion.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The preacher explicitly deconstructs Elijah as a moral hero, emphasizing he is 'just like us' and his 'aura' is actually God's.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides the theocentric reading: Elijah is a 'prism' for God's light.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; moving from the fear of judgment to the assurance of mercy.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic grace; salvation is a work of God alone.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the Old Testament narrative to the work of Christ is seamless and structurally sound.
spanning_punten: The tension between God's holiness (judgment) and God's heart (mercy).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He stepped into the place of judgment alone, and took it all upon himself.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a 'hostile Power' that 'infects' and 'works death'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the primary narrative program. Human actors are correctly positioned as helpers or receivers.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon avoids the 'Devoir' trap effectively.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Death/Sin) is already presented as a cosmic force.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God raises the boy) correctly precedes and enables Ethics (Elijah's witness).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in theocentric preaching that uses the actantial structure of the text to point directly to the Gospel.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'magic' of the name Elijah, Greimasian analysis reveals that Elijah is merely a functional 'Helper' to the divine 'Subject'.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the widow's oil; semiotics explains the widow's role as the 'Receiver' of a value (Life) she cannot produce.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'tension' in the sermon is a modal conflict between human 'impotence' and divine 'power'.

volledige_subject_lijst: God (raised, gives, sends, brought, behaves, raises, calls)
Elijah (stood, went, stayed, snatched, carried, demanded)
Jesus (looked, had compassion, stepped, spoke, took)
appendices.notities: The sermon explicitly uses Rutledge's rule by making God the subject of the most critical active verbs (save, raise, give).
